title: Welcome To My Blog

This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Test Jupyter post
text:
This is a post with executable code.

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 4 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()




Figure 1: A line plot on a polar axis

title: #001: hockey stats
text:
Today we’re going to explore some sports data. While watching my favorite hockey team this year (the Philadeplphia Flyers), I’ve felt like I barely know the players. There was a lot of turnover in the roster in the past couple of years.
This got me thinking. Which year did the Flyers roster experience the most turnover?
To answer this question, we will turn to hockey-reference.com/.
First, let’s download a table of all Flyers players across the team’s history. Rather than scraping the website, I manually accessed the data here

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 5 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()




Figure 1: A line plot on a polar axis
